Award.AwardTitle: Titan: High Angular Resolution Synergistic Groundbased Observations during the Cassini Era
Award.AbstractNarration: This project focuses on the atmosphere of Saturn's moon Titan. The PI, along with a supported Ph.D. researcher and a graduate student, will conduct ground-based observations of Titan using 8 to 10 meter class telescopes equipped with adaptive optics systems and integral field spectrographs. These observations will be combined with in situ data from the Cassini spacecraft, with the goal of tracking the distribution of methane clouds and hazes. The interpretation of the data will be made via this group's radiative transfer model, which will be improved by the addition of new laboratory data on methane transitions and new corrections to the treatment of methane absorption and aerosol scattering. These calculations will yield the 3-dimensional cloud/haze distribution, which will eventually reveal the circulation patterns in Titan's atmosphere. This project will train one or more students in modern observational techniques involving adaptive optics, as well as assist in the development of these techniques at the engineering level. The public will be engaged through the release of images showing the benefit of adaptive optics and highlighting the similarities and differences between the atmospheres of Titan and Earth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the course of this project we used multiple "night-vision" cameras on the world's largest optical telescopes to look through the thick smog on Saturn's largest moon, Titan. The special cameras are needed because Titan is covered by a thick aerosol smog that obscures the surface, and with regular cameras Titan looks like an orange ball. With the special instruments, we measured the weather conditions  near the surface, where it is so cold that natural gas rains out of the sky. Although we don’t know if the natural gas seeps out of the ground or not, we do know it exists near the poles in lakes. Understanding how much methane there is in atmosphere, and how humid it is in different places, tells us about whether the methane is evaporating from the lakes or not. Taking pictures of how the smog moves around also gives us clues to understanding how the atmosphere of this frigid world works and knowing the weather patterns is important for understanding how far away from where the methane is evaporating should be humid. Our main finding was that it’s more humid near the north pole, where the lakes are, and is it dry near the equator, where the Cassini spacecraft saw sand-dunes. Our pictures of how the smog has been changing over the last decade are really valuable, because they will be studied with the type of models that are used for predicting the weather to see if we really understand what is happening in the atmosphere or if there is something important in our understanding that is missing.
